class_notes: Prior completion of PSYC 200W: Laboratory Methods.  Enrollment is limited to Juniors and Seniors only. The origins of language are among the greatest mysteries in human evolution. A comparative approach to finding answers examines the communicative faculties of our closest living relatives, the nonhuman primates. In this seminar course, students will take an in-depth look at findings in primate communication and evaluate their relevance to language evolution. Topics will include the cognition underlying primate communication; the neural mechanisms of vocal production and perception in humans and nonhumans; the implications of language-like phenomena in animal communication, such as word-like external reference and syntax-like call combinations; lessons from research on language-trained apes; the constraints of learning and flexibility in primate calls and gestures; and the somewhat nebulous concepts of meaning, information, and intentionality as applied to communication. Students will also gain first-hand experience with the techniques and analytical software that researchers use to explore these topics.
